aws::graph::propositions: # Stits Playmate SA11A Airplane Accident at Bridgeport Municipal Airport
Stits Playmate SA11A airplane with registration N76WS was involved in an accident.
The accident occurred on July 29, 2014, at approximately 1305 central daylight time.
The accident occurred at Bridgeport Municipal Airport (XBP) in Bridgeport, Texas.
The airplane was substantially damaged in the accident.
The airline transport rated pilot was not injured in the accident.
The airplane was registered to a private individual.
The airplane was operated by a private individual.
The flight was conducted under the provisions of 14 Code of Federal Regulations Part 91 as a personal flight.
Visual meteorological conditions prevailed during the flight.
A flight plan was not filed for the flight.
The flight was departing Bridgeport Municipal Airport at the time of the accident.
The pilot departed from an airport located about 25 miles southeast of Bridgeport Municipal Airport earlier.
The wind was 8-10 mph from 150 degrees at the departure airport.
As the pilot approached Bridgeport Municipal Airport, the pilot observed the winds to be 8-10 mph from 150-170 degrees.
The pilot conducted a normal landing on runway 18 at Bridgeport Municipal Airport.
The pilot refueled the airplane at Bridgeport Municipal Airport.
About 30 minutes after arriving at Bridgeport Municipal Airport, the pilot planned to return to the original airport.
The pilot noticed the winds were now 8-10 mph and varying from 050 to 090 degrees.
The pilot selected runway 36 for departure from Bridgeport Municipal Airport.
During takeoff, when the airplane was 10-15 feet in the air, the airplane made a descending left turn.
The pilot stayed in the traffic pattern and landed on the runway.
The pilot checked the flight controls after landing.
The flight controls appeared to respond correctly during the pilot's check.
The pilot departed Bridgeport Municipal Airport again.
After becoming airborne on the second takeoff attempt, the airplane made another descending left turn.
The airplane did not respond to the pilot's control inputs during the second takeoff attempt.
The pilot reduced power during the second takeoff attempt.
The pilot landed the airplane in the grass near the runway.
The airplane slid across a taxiway after landing in the grass.
The airplane impacted a tree at the airport perimeter.
The airplane impacted a fence at the airport perimeter.
Examination of the airplane by the NTSB Investigator revealed substantial damage to the left wing.
Examination of the airplane by the NTSB Investigator revealed substantial damage to the right wing.
Examination of the airplane by the NTSB Investigator revealed substantial damage to the fuselage.
Control continuity of the ailerons was established with no abnormalities noted.
The accident involved windshear or thunderstorm during takeoff.
The accident involved loss of control in flight as the defining event.
The accident involved an uncontrolled descent.
The accident involved collision with terrain/object (non-CFIT).

text:
# Factual Information

## History of Flight

| Takeoff | Windshear or thunderstorm |
| Takeoff | Loss of control in flight (Defining event) |
| Uncontrolled descent | Collision with terr/obj (non-CFIT) |

On July 29, 2014, about 1305 central daylight time, a Stits Playmate SA11A airplane, N76WS, impacted terrain at the Bridgeport Municipal Airport (XBP), Bridgeport, Texas. The airline transport rated pilot was not injured and the airplane was substantially damaged. The airplane was registered to and operated by a private individual, under the provisions of 14 Code of Federal Regulations Part 91 as a personal flight. Visual meteorological conditions prevailed and a flight plan was not filed. The flight was departing XBP at the time of the accident.

The pilot departed from an airport located about 25 miles southeast of XBP earlier, and the wind was 8-10 mph from 150 degrees. As he approached his destination airport, he observed the winds to be 8-10 mph from 150-170 degrees, and then conducted a normal landing on runway 18. After refueling the airplane and about 30 minutes after arriving, he planned to return to his original airport. He noticed the winds were now 8-10 mph and varying from 050 to 090 degrees. The pilot then selected runway 36 for departure. During the takeoff, when the airplane was 10-15 feet in the air, the airplane made a descending left turn. He then stayed in the traffic pattern and landed on the runway. The pilot checked the flight controls and the controls appeared to respond correctly. He departed the airport and after becoming airborne, the airplane made another descending left turn. The airplane did not respond to his control inputs, so he reduced power and landed in the grass near the runway. The airplane slid across a taxiway and impacted a tree and fence, at the airport perimeter.

Examination of the airplane by the NTSB Investigator revealed substantial damage to the left and right wings, and fuselage. Control continuity of the ailerons was established with no abnormalities noted.
